docs.title: Dining with Dainis & Izabela
docs.text:
Welcome to the cookbook where we capture the dishes we prepare together. Each recipe is stored as Markdown so it stays versioned, searchable, and easy to update. Use the navigation to the left (or the recipe cards on mobile) to jump straight into the latest dish, then edit the Markdown whenever you want to tweak the instructions or add tasting notes.

We process every photo and URL through a staging workflow before it lands in this directory, then deploy the polished site via GitHub Pages—so the live page always matches what you reviewed and approved.

docs.title: Lasagna Bolognese al Forno
docs.text:
This lasagna emulates the Serious Eats take on al forno Bolognese—slow-simmered meat sauce, tender sheets, and a touch of béchamel to keep it creamy while the top crisps up.

Source: Serious Eats—Lasagna Bolognese al Forno

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 tbsp olive oil
  • 1 large onion, finely chopped
  • 2 carrots, finely diced
  • 2 celery stalks, finely diced
  • 4 garlic cloves, smashed
  • 500 g ground beef (or a mix of beef and pork)
  • 150 g pancetta, finely chopped
  • 1 cup dry white wine
  • 1 cup whole milk
  • 1 1/2 cups canned crushed tomatoes
  • 2 tbsp tomato paste
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 1 sprig fresh thyme
  • Salt and freshly ground pepper
  • 12 lasagna sheets (fresh or dried)
  • 1 cup grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, plus extra for serving
  • 1 cup shredded mozzarella (optional)
  • 2 cups béchamel (butter, flour, milk, nutmeg)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Warm olive oil in a heavy pot, then add onion, carrot, and celery; sweat until soft and translucent. Stir in garlic and toast briefly.
  2. Add pancetta and ground meat, breaking it up as it browns. When the meat is fully cooked, deglaze with wine and reduce by half.
  3. Stir in milk and simmer until almost absorbed, then add crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, bay leaf, and thyme. Season with salt and pepper and let the ragù simmer very gently for 45–60 minutes (add water if it gets too thick).
  4. Preheat oven to 190 °C (375 °F). Have your béchamel and grated cheeses ready.
  5. Layer in a deep baking dish: a slick of béchamel, lasagna sheets, ragù, shredded mozzarella/Parmigiano, repeat until you finish with a final layer of béchamel and a generous dusting of Parmigiano.
  6. Bake for 30–35 minutes until golden and bubbling, then rest 15 minutes before slicing so the layers set.

Tip: Save the ragù in the fridge for a day—it develops a deeper flavour and reheats beautifully for leftovers.

docs.title: Why this version
docs.text:
A layered aubergine-and-beef bake inspired by the Guardian’s classic, updated with a quicker bechamel and extra oregano for warmth. Keep it bubbling in the oven while the Greek salad gets assembled.

Source: Guardian - How to cook perfect moussaka

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 aubergines, sliced lengthwise
  • 400 g minced lamb or beef
  • 1 onion, diced
  • 2 garlic cloves
  • 400 g crushed tomatoes
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 2 tbsp tomato paste
  • 1 cup grated kefalotyri or parmesan
  • Bechamel (butter, flour, milk, nutmeg)
  • Olive oil, salt, pepper, oregano

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Salt the aubergine slices, roast until golden, and pat dry.
  2. Brown the meat with onion, garlic, tomato paste, cinnamon, and oregano, then add crushed tomatoes and simmer.
  3. Layer aubergines, ragout, and bechamel in a casserole, finish with grated cheese, and bake at 190 °C for 35–40 minutes.
  4. Let rest 15 minutes before slicing so the layers settle.

Note: The leftovers taste even better the next day when reheated slowly in the oven.

docs.title: Rhode Island Chowder
docs.text:
Creamy mussel, clam and potato stew inspired by the Rhode Island recipe. The saffron-yellow broth hides a gentle hit of smoke from the clams.

Source: Serious Eats—dairy-free Rhode Island clam chowder

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 kg mussels and clams, scrubbed
  • 2 potatoes, diced
  • 1 onion, diced
  • 2 stalks celery
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 2 cups vegetable stock
  • Cream or coconut milk to finish

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Sweat onion, celery, and potatoes in butter until soft.
  2. Add stock, bay leaf, clams, and cook until the shells open, then stir in cream.
  3. Remove shells, season with sea salt and finish with chopped parsley.

Serve with thick crusty bread and a drizzle of olive oil.

docs.title: Steam-Braised Sea Bass
docs.text:
A delicate fish dish referenced from Serious Eats—chill the bass in a bamboo steamer, tuck in ginger and scallions, and finish with a splash of ponzu.

Source: Serious Eats—River Cottage steam-braised sea bass

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 sea bass fillets
  • 2 slices ginger
  • 2 scallions, cut into 3 cm lengths
  • 1 tsp sesame oil
  • Soy sauce and ponzu to serve
  • Optional: a touch of rice wine

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Lay ginger and scallions on the bottom of the steamer, place the sea bass skin-side up, drizzle with sesame oil.
  2. Steam for 8–10 minutes (until the flesh flakes), remove, and top with fresh scallion oil.
  3. Serve with ponzu or soy, and a side of jasmine rice.

Tip: Reserve the steaming liquid for soup stock—salty, umami-rich base for next day’s broth.
